JOHNS HOPKINS UNIVERSITY
VOL. XVIII, NO. 6.

GETZ ENTHRALLS STUDENTS
Holds Mass-Meeting Spell-Bound While
He Talks of the Trustees and
Faculty's Regard for Him.

NEws-LETTER

THE
is happy that
it is able to present this morning a
verbatim account of the more interesting portions of Charles Leland Getz's speech at the mass-meeting on Thursday. With the students wrought to a high pitch, with
recriminations hurtling through the
air, with half a dozen attempting to
speak at once, it was a difficult task
to catch the words of wisdom which
fell from Alumnus Getz's ruby lips.
The entire NEws-LETTER staff and
a special corps of stenographers,
however, accomplished the feat. It
is a matter of deep and unbounding
regret that we cannot give the oration in full. All of it was important,
but Walter, appointed censor, inclines to the view that the following are the choicest passages of what
is in the future to find a well merited .
place in "Modern American Eloquence," Volume m00006. Said
Getz, when the applause had subsided:
"Mr. Chairman, fellows, and Mr.
Carter !"
Mr. Carter--I won't have him
make fun of me!
Mr. Getz, ignoring this interruption, continued :
"My friends and fellow countrymen, I come from the heyday of
the busy world down town to counsel patience; to advise you not to
strike., That were a blow too,hard
to bear. [Applause and cries of
"Hear, head"' It is hopeless to
buck up against the faculty ; you
must submit.
"Now, when I was arrested in my
junior year here [frantic applause]
numerous members of the faculty
called upon me with tears in their
eyes and told me they were worried and sincerely trusted the Dean
would not take the matter up and
investigate, with the result that the
University would suffer the calamity of my non-attendance. [Laughter.]
"Whether 'twas my charming
personality [a voice, recognized to
be Paul Carter's:"Oh, you bebby !"]
or the desire which the faculty had
to see me and the University prosper, I know not. I care not. What
is more, at this present important
moment, important for you, I inquire not. [Applause.] But it is a
fact that the faculty was concerned
about what was to happen, and although you are not me, [cries of
"Thank Heaven"' I will use my
influence with the professors to have
vour sentences remitted. [Cries of
"Bravo" and "Hear him."]
(Continued on page 5, col. 3.)

BALTIMORE, MD., NOVEMBER 17, 1913.

HOPKINS HAZERS GO TO JAIL
Twenty "Sophs" and "Freshies" Spend Half Hour in Cold
Stone Cells at Northern.
Groundkeeper Chalk Prefers the Charges--Students are Suspended
but Return on Conditions that Dissatisfy All Students.
Twenty undergraduates charged with the disturbance of the peace
spent a short time in the cold stone cells of the Northern Police Station
Monday night as a result of a hazing party held at Homewood, which
was rudely brought to a close when Groundkeeper Alvin T. Chalk summoned the auto patrol and a squad of "cops" to arrest the sophomores
and freshmen.
Lieutenant Casey, genial and polite, was host at the police station,
and made the visit of the students very pleasant. Before consigning- them
to the cells he advised that a member of the Police Board be communicated with, and Morris A. Soper, president of the Board, advised Lieutenant Casey to release the - men on their recognizance to appear at a
hearing at .
g o'clock Tuesday morning.
Before Justice Griffin, at the trial, Groundkeeper Chalk refused to
press his charge of the night before, and the men were dismissed.
Dean Griffin—the fate of the men seems to have been in the hands
of Griffins—took a different view of the situation, however, and the men
were indefinitely suspended from the University as soon as he learned of
the proceedings. In two days, however, the sophomores returned to their
lectures on probation set forth in the four conditions to which the entire
student body has expressed hearty disapproval.
The entire proceeding was_ file result of. an -innocent little hazing
party," which the sophomores had not intended should bring about such
an embarrassing state of affairs.
The -sophs" met secretly Monday noon and decided to have a little
fun with several selected members of the freshman class.
The party assembled around a bonfire on the field that will be the
campus of the new University at Homewood. Speeches were made, and
then an impromptu. wrestling bout was arranged. For fear the freshmen would take cold a mild medicine was administered and the party
adjourned.
As they were walking down Charles street, however, a large automobile slipped up from behind and a squad of policemen surrounded
the party. They had been summoned by Groundkeeper Chalk, who had
been advised by telephone that a riot was occurring. As soon as Chalk
got the message he called the Northern Station, and the auto was dispatched with eight patrolmen.
Just as the police overtook' the hazers, Chalk appeared. The police
said they could not make any charges, as they had not seen or been
aware of any disturbances of the peace. Chalk looked at the Hopkins
men and, although he knew them, told the police to make the arrests.
The party was too large to be accommodated by the patrol all at
once, and three trips were made before all the men settled in their cells.
, Several of those Nvho were in the party, however, managed to get
away before the police overtook the party going down Charles street.
These men were not arrested, but when their less fortunate companions
were dismissed by the dean they, too, appeared and gave themselves up.
Twenty-eight men were thus suspended.
At a mass-meeting, held last Thursday in Hopkins Hall, the sophomores were advised by the student body to sign the dean's four conditions and become members of the University again.
The student body, however, made it evident that they were very
hostile to the sophomores' submitting to the Collegiate Board's impositions, and, while the men were advised to sign, they were assured that
it was done so because of necessity and not because the student body
was supporting the faculty's position in the matter.
The undergraduate body is still dissatisfied, and will make efforts to
have the "sentence" commuted. It was the general opinion that the
Board of Collegiate Studies be allowed to meet again before the student
body made any pleas. If there is no action taken at the next meeting of
the Board, leaders of the undergraduates say they will then ask that the
conditions of reinstatement be made invalid.
The conditions are to be found in the dean's letter published in
another column.

Does First Trick.

On the muddiest field that the
rooters have seen for years, and in
a steady drizzle, the 'Varsity
downed Western Maryland Saturday by a score of 15 to o.
The Westminsterites won the toss,

Western Maryland's 40-yard line.
Western Maryland was penalized

couldn't make the grade ; the ball

The first score came after nine
minutes , of play. Barclay intercepted a forward pass, and after a
gain of two yards, Tippett's toe,
swinging like a pendulum, put over
a beautiful goal.
In the second period it was Western Maryland's ball on their own

then Bowers made his spectacular

his right sideline all the way over to

A most thrilling hunt took place
last Friday when Mr. Frank Kimball Leland, master of the Homewood Kennels, led a party of thirty hounds and twelve horsemen
through the Homewood estate and
Wymans Park on a bull chase.
The wild animal was not cornered
in the suburbs, but took flight down
Charles street. At North avenue,
however, several of the hunters
dropped off at the Northhampton
for a bottle of sack and some roast
meat. The bull was eventually treed
in Greenmount Cemetery near John
Wilkes Booth's grave. It was
promptly shot.
* *
A charmingly arranged tea was
given on Wednesday afternoon at
Economic Manor, the country place
of Mr. James A. Dushane Penniman on the Schooly Peneplane, in
honor of Miss McCormick, this
season's interesting and accomplished debutante. Miss Geissel
sang several soprano arias.

BALTIMORE, MD., NOV. 17, 1913.
Our Opinion.

It was the opinion of the entire
undergraduate body that the suspended sophomores not sign the
"terms of reinstatement" offered by
the Board of Collegiate Studies.
That they did so was a question
of necessity, and not because the
student body thought it proper.
The Board offered to receive
the sophomores back in .the fold
on those famous "four conditions."
it was a question of signing or being dismissed. The faulty had
made up its mind, and like the professional -.disciplinarians at West
Point and Annapolis, refused to
hear the "other side." So the sophomores were advised to sign. The
result is that the whole student body
is dissatisfied.
The faculty has often, during the
past few years, asked the counsel
and co-operation of several students
on questions that really were not
"the students' business ;" but the
men summoned did give their opinions and advice.
Now that the student body wishes
to talk to the Board of Collegiate
Studies through representatives, it
is pointed out that the faculty has
made up its mind and is not to be
shaken from its position.
There" is no co-operation, and
there is no unity. There is an open
split.
The Board of Collegiate Studies
has either not considered the matter thoroughly enough or has failed
to appreciate the fact that the socalled punishment affects not only
students involved, but several of the
college activities as well.
The football team suffers, the Cotillon Board suffers, the Musical
Clubs are depleted. Does the faculty intend this? If it does, it has

reduced itself to the plane of high
school teachers. The student body
can righteously claim the faculty has
been unjust.
Furthermore, the student body believes that did. the conditions imposed not affect the college activities, it would also be unjust.
Hazing is a high-handed offense
in the. academic eye. Technically.
all students know the faculty will
punish offenders. But what is to
constitute this punishment? Shall
those caught be sentenced to a slap
in the face, or its more dignified expression, the exclusion from social,
athletic and musical activity?
THE NEWS-LETTER thinks the
original suspension of two days a
sufficient punishment. By that means
the faculty has expressed its disapproval. Let it now stop! There
is no honor in knocking a man down
and then beating him further.
THE NEWS-LETTER, however, still
believes the faculty can be led to see
the error of its way, and can relieve
the sophomores of the probation imposed upon them.
THE NEWS-LETTER asks the faculty to do this.
Chalk: The Man of Destiny.

The whole situation at the time
of the arrest was in the hands of
Alvin T. Chalk, groundkeeper at
Homewood. He called the police
by telephone, but when they appeared they could find none of the
riotous proceedings in progress
which Chalk had described over the
phone. They told him they would
not make arrests unless charges
were preferred.
This is the conversation as reported by the sophomores and
freshmen:
Police—"We can't make any arrests unless some one prefers a
charge. We haven't seen anything
out of the ordinary."
Chalk—"Well, it lies with me
then. I charge them with disturbing the peace." •
Then the sophomores climbed the
little flight of steps into the dark
blue auto. One freshman went in
the first load.
Chalk caused the arrest of the
Hopkins men.
If the trustees of the University
were to have an oyster roast on
Homewood Field, would Chalk order their arrest?

DR. EDWARD H. GRIEE1N,

Dean of the College Faculty, the
Johns Hopkins University, Baltimore, Aid.
DEAR DR. GR1FEIN :

As the president and secretary of
the Class of "Naughty Two"—than
which we believe no subsequent class
has been a more flagrant transgressor of college rules (even including the present sophomore class)
we desire to respectfully express our
disapproval of the conditions on
which the suspended men are offered reinstatement. Under more or
less similar circumstances, though
probably more aggravated, certain
members of our class were reinstated when the class unanimously
resolved "that it would henceforth
refrain from all hazing, and would
use its influence to effect a discontinuance of the practice at the University." This resolution was strictly adhered to, and our influence
with the other classes prevented any
further trouble during our college
life.
We frankly 'Etate that the conditions imposed by von are so humiliating as to justify those who can
afford it to seek some other college. .
-In our class a man's promise was
as good as his bond, and was so construed by the University. Provided
the sophomore class is willing to
give its promise as we did, we see
n0- good to be accomplished by the
period .of probation and the other
punishments included, and we see .
much harm.
While we cannot commit our class
to these views, • we •-•believe they
would unanimously concur if a
. .
.meeting could be held. .
This letter is prompted by our interest in the future success of the
University, and because we think
von are making a mistake.
Yours very truly,
(Signed):
OGLE AtARBVRY,
President.
(Signed):
RALPH C. SIIARRETTS,

JOHNS HOPKINS UNIVERSITY
VOL. XVIII, NO. 6.

GETZ ENTHRALLS STUDENTS
Holds Mass-Meeting Spell-Bound While
He Talks of the Trustees and
Faculty's Regard for Him.

NEws-LETTER

THE
is happy that
it is able to present this morning a
verbatim account of the more interesting portions of Charles Leland Getz's speech at the mass-meeting on Thursday. With the students wrought to a high pitch, with
recriminations hurtling through the
air, with half a dozen attempting to
speak at once, it was a difficult task
to catch the words of wisdom which
fell from Alumnus Getz's ruby lips.
The entire NEws-LETTER staff and
a special corps of stenographers,
however, accomplished the feat. It
is a matter of deep and unbounding
regret that we cannot give the oration in full. All of it was important,
but Walter, appointed censor, inclines to the view that the following are the choicest passages of what
is in the future to find a well merited .
place in "Modern American Eloquence," Volume m00006. Said
Getz, when the applause had subsided:
"Mr. Chairman, fellows, and Mr.
Carter !"
Mr. Carter--I won't have him
make fun of me!
Mr. Getz, ignoring this interruption, continued :
"My friends and fellow countrymen, I come from the heyday of
the busy world down town to counsel patience; to advise you not to
strike., That were a blow too,hard
to bear. [Applause and cries of
"Hear, head"' It is hopeless to
buck up against the faculty ; you
must submit.
"Now, when I was arrested in my
junior year here [frantic applause]
numerous members of the faculty
called upon me with tears in their
eyes and told me they were worried and sincerely trusted the Dean
would not take the matter up and
investigate, with the result that the
University would suffer the calamity of my non-attendance. [Laughter.]
"Whether 'twas my charming
personality [a voice, recognized to
be Paul Carter's:"Oh, you bebby !"]
or the desire which the faculty had
to see me and the University prosper, I know not. I care not. What
is more, at this present important
moment, important for you, I inquire not. [Applause.] But it is a
fact that the faculty was concerned
about what was to happen, and although you are not me, [cries of
"Thank Heaven"' I will use my
influence with the professors to have
vour sentences remitted. [Cries of
"Bravo" and "Hear him."]
(Continued on page 5, col. 3.)

BALTIMORE, MD., NOVEMBER 17, 1913.

HOPKINS HAZERS GO TO JAIL
Twenty "Sophs" and "Freshies" Spend Half Hour in Cold
Stone Cells at Northern.
Groundkeeper Chalk Prefers the Charges--Students are Suspended
but Return on Conditions that Dissatisfy All Students.
Twenty undergraduates charged with the disturbance of the peace
spent a short time in the cold stone cells of the Northern Police Station
Monday night as a result of a hazing party held at Homewood, which
was rudely brought to a close when Groundkeeper Alvin T. Chalk summoned the auto patrol and a squad of "cops" to arrest the sophomores
and freshmen.
Lieutenant Casey, genial and polite, was host at the police station,
and made the visit of the students very pleasant. Before consigning- them
to the cells he advised that a member of the Police Board be communicated with, and Morris A. Soper, president of the Board, advised Lieutenant Casey to release the - men on their recognizance to appear at a
hearing at .
g o'clock Tuesday morning.
Before Justice Griffin, at the trial, Groundkeeper Chalk refused to
press his charge of the night before, and the men were dismissed.
Dean Griffin—the fate of the men seems to have been in the hands
of Griffins—took a different view of the situation, however, and the men
were indefinitely suspended from the University as soon as he learned of
the proceedings. In two days, however, the sophomores returned to their
lectures on probation set forth in the four conditions to which the entire
student body has expressed hearty disapproval.
The entire proceeding was_ file result of. an -innocent little hazing
party," which the sophomores had not intended should bring about such
an embarrassing state of affairs.
The -sophs" met secretly Monday noon and decided to have a little
fun with several selected members of the freshman class.
The party assembled around a bonfire on the field that will be the
campus of the new University at Homewood. Speeches were made, and
then an impromptu. wrestling bout was arranged. For fear the freshmen would take cold a mild medicine was administered and the party
adjourned.
As they were walking down Charles street, however, a large automobile slipped up from behind and a squad of policemen surrounded
the party. They had been summoned by Groundkeeper Chalk, who had
been advised by telephone that a riot was occurring. As soon as Chalk
got the message he called the Northern Station, and the auto was dispatched with eight patrolmen.
Just as the police overtook' the hazers, Chalk appeared. The police
said they could not make any charges, as they had not seen or been
aware of any disturbances of the peace. Chalk looked at the Hopkins
men and, although he knew them, told the police to make the arrests.
The party was too large to be accommodated by the patrol all at
once, and three trips were made before all the men settled in their cells.
, Several of those Nvho were in the party, however, managed to get
away before the police overtook the party going down Charles street.
These men were not arrested, but when their less fortunate companions
were dismissed by the dean they, too, appeared and gave themselves up.
Twenty-eight men were thus suspended.
At a mass-meeting, held last Thursday in Hopkins Hall, the sophomores were advised by the student body to sign the dean's four conditions and become members of the University again.
The student body, however, made it evident that they were very
hostile to the sophomores' submitting to the Collegiate Board's impositions, and, while the men were advised to sign, they were assured that
it was done so because of necessity and not because the student body
was supporting the faculty's position in the matter.
The undergraduate body is still dissatisfied, and will make efforts to
have the "sentence" commuted. It was the general opinion that the
Board of Collegiate Studies be allowed to meet again before the student
body made any pleas. If there is no action taken at the next meeting of
the Board, leaders of the undergraduates say they will then ask that the
conditions of reinstatement be made invalid.
The conditions are to be found in the dean's letter published in
another column.

Wilkes Booth's grave. It was
promptly shot.

BALTIMORE, MD., NOV. 17, 1913.
Our Opinion.

It was the opinion of the entire
undergraduate body that the suspended sophomores not sign the
"terms of reinstatement" offered by
the Board of Collegiate Studies.
That they did so was a question
of necessity, and not because the
student body thought it proper.
The Board offered to receive
the sophomores back in .the fold
on those famous "four conditions."
it was a question of signing or being dismissed. The faulty had
made up its mind, and like the professional -.disciplinarians at West
Point and Annapolis, refused to
hear the "other side." So the sophomores were advised to sign. The
result is that the whole student body
is dissatisfied.
The faculty has often, during the
past few years, asked the counsel
and co-operation of several students
on questions that really were not
"the students' business ;" but the
men summoned did give their opinions and advice.
Now that the student body wishes
to talk to the Board of Collegiate
Studies through representatives, it
is pointed out that the faculty has
made up its mind and is not to be
shaken from its position.
There" is no co-operation, and
there is no unity. There is an open
split.
The Board of Collegiate Studies
has either not considered the matter thoroughly enough or has failed
to appreciate the fact that the socalled punishment affects not only
students involved, but several of the
college activities as well.
The football team suffers, the Cotillon Board suffers, the Musical
Clubs are depleted. Does the faculty intend this? If it does, it has

reduced itself to the plane of high
school teachers. The student body
can righteously claim the faculty has
been unjust.
Furthermore, the student body believes that did. the conditions imposed not affect the college activities, it would also be unjust.
Hazing is a high-handed offense
in the. academic eye. Technically.
all students know the faculty will
punish offenders. But what is to
constitute this punishment? Shall
those caught be sentenced to a slap
in the face, or its more dignified expression, the exclusion from social,
athletic and musical activity?
THE NEWS-LETTER thinks the
original suspension of two days a
sufficient punishment. By that means
the faculty has expressed its disapproval. Let it now stop! There
is no honor in knocking a man down
and then beating him further.
THE NEWS-LETTER, however, still
believes the faculty can be led to see
the error of its way, and can relieve
the sophomores of the probation imposed upon them.
THE NEWS-LETTER asks the faculty to do this.
Chalk: The Man of Destiny.

The whole situation at the time
of the arrest was in the hands of
Alvin T. Chalk, groundkeeper at
Homewood. He called the police
by telephone, but when they appeared they could find none of the
riotous proceedings in progress
which Chalk had described over the
phone. They told him they would
not make arrests unless charges
were preferred.
This is the conversation as reported by the sophomores and
freshmen:
Police—"We can't make any arrests unless some one prefers a
charge. We haven't seen anything
out of the ordinary."
Chalk—"Well, it lies with me
then. I charge them with disturbing the peace." •
Then the sophomores climbed the
little flight of steps into the dark
blue auto. One freshman went in
the first load.
Chalk caused the arrest of the
Hopkins men.
If the trustees of the University
were to have an oyster roast on
Homewood Field, would Chalk order their arrest?

DR. EDWARD H. GRIEE1N,

Dean of the College Faculty, the
Johns Hopkins University, Baltimore, Aid.
DEAR DR. GR1FEIN :

As the president and secretary of
the Class of "Naughty Two"—than
which we believe no subsequent class
has been a more flagrant transgressor of college rules (even including the present sophomore class)
we desire to respectfully express our
disapproval of the conditions on
which the suspended men are offered reinstatement. Under more or
less similar circumstances, though
probably more aggravated, certain
members of our class were reinstated when the class unanimously
resolved "that it would henceforth
refrain from all hazing, and would
use its influence to effect a discontinuance of the practice at the University." This resolution was strictly adhered to, and our influence
with the other classes prevented any
further trouble during our college
life.
We frankly 'Etate that the conditions imposed by von are so humiliating as to justify those who can
afford it to seek some other college. .
-In our class a man's promise was
as good as his bond, and was so construed by the University. Provided
the sophomore class is willing to
give its promise as we did, we see
n0- good to be accomplished by the
period .of probation and the other
punishments included, and we see .
much harm.
While we cannot commit our class
to these views, • we •-•believe they
would unanimously concur if a
. .
.meeting could be held. .
This letter is prompted by our interest in the future success of the
University, and because we think
von are making a mistake.
Yours very truly,
(Signed):
OGLE AtARBVRY,
President.
(Signed):

reading at the head of the table
while waiting for the arrival of Dr.
Scott: and every now and then
glances up at the one, lone co-ed.
Just a little reading, just a little
glance,
Fascinating pastime, you musn't
look askance.
Think you she is fetching? Has a
little charm?
Well, a little flirting, really isn't
harm.
